security: Revealing the identities and activities of U.S. participants in the WPC could expose them to scrutiny or harm, as the cable notes observations regarding their participation in discussions on the Vietnam War and other related events.
summary: A cable from Budapest details observations on U.S. participants at the World Peace Council (WPC) meeting, including Sidney Peck's speech on the Vietnam War, the posthumous award to Martin Luther King Jr., and the reelection of Herbert Aptheker and Carlton Goodlett to the Presidential Board.
summary_one_paragraph: A SECRET cable from Budapest, dated May 19, 1971, reports on the final coverage of the World Peace Council (WPC) meeting that concluded on May 16. It highlights the activities and affiliations of U.S. participants, including Sidney Peck's speech on the Vietnam War, the posthumous award of the Joliot Curie Gold Medal to Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. (accepted by Rev. Ralph Abernathy and Rev. W. Walker), and the presence of William Douthard and Mrs. Addie Wyatt at the medal presentation. Additionally, U.S. delegates Ruth Gage-Colby and Sylvia Kuscher spoke at a meeting of Indochinese and American delegates, and Americans Herbert Aptheker and Carlton Goodlett were reelected to the Presidential Board.
title: Observations on U.S. Participants at World Peace Council Meeting
